title: About
content:
I am currently a PhD student at Princeton University in the Quantitative and Computational Biology (QCB) program. My research goals are to develop useful statistical methodologies to analyze high-dimensional data.

Prior to attending the QCB program, I worked in the Storey Lab as a research scientist. Please see my Research, R packages or GitHub page for additional details.

Education

  MPS in Information Science, Cornell University
  BS in Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University


General research interests

  Statistical methodologies
  Meta-analysis studies
  Writing R packages
  Reproducible research


Contact
   Email
snippet: I am currently a PhD student at Princeton University in the Quantitative and Computational Biology (QCB) program. My research goals are to develop useful statistical methodologies to analyze high-dimensional data.

title: Research
content:
The current focus of my research is to (i) understand the relationship between sequencing depth and statistical power in sequencing studies and (ii) improve multiple hypothesis testing in high-dimensional data.

Please click on a project below for more details.




Predicting adequate read depth in sequencing studies to maximize statistical power

  
A common problem when designing a sequencing experiment is determining how many reads to sequence. Usually researchers will try to find a similar experiment (which can be difficult) or run a pilot study to guide their choice in read depth. In either case, subsampling methodologies are applied to assess whether more reads should be sequenced to maximize statistical power in the experiment. However, these methodologies do not provide guidelines for how many additional reads should be sequenced. We have developed a parametric model, superSeq, to predict the increase in power from an increasing sequencing depth. Therefore, researchers can use our model to determine how many reads, if any, need to be sequenced to maximize statistical power in a completed sequencing experiment.


Presentations

  Icahn Think & Drink (2015): pdf



Posters

  Bioconductor (2015): pdf




Collaborators

  David G. Robinson
  John D. Storey


  






 Optimal discovery procedure for generalized study designs
  
  Under construction

title: Software
content:
Bioconductor


  
    edge: The edge package implements methods for carrying out differential expression analyses of genome-wide gene expression studies. Authors: John D. Storey, Jeffrey T. Leek and Andrew J. Bass
  
  
    biobroom: The biobroom package contains tidying methods for S4 objects in Bioconductor. Authors: Andrew J. Bass, David G. Robinson, Emily Nelson and John D. Storey
  
  
    qvalue: The qvalue package estimates the q-values for a given set of p-values. See
the shiny app for an interactive version! Author: John D. Storey Contributors: Andrew J. Bass, Alan Dabney, David G. Robinson
  
  
    subSeq: The subSeq package subsamples high throughput sequencing count data for use in experiment design and analysis. Authors: David G. Robinson and John D. Storey Contributors: Andrew J. Bass
snippet: All of our software (written in R) is intended for high-dimensional data analysis in computational biology and can be downloaded from Bioconductor.
